    string email

  PHONE {

    int user_id FK

    int id PK
    int user_id FK
    int requested_phone_id FK
    int offered_phone_id FK
    string status
    string comment
  }

    int id PK
    string name
    string description
  }

    int id PK
    string text
    int swap_request_id FK
    string haha

  PHONE ||--o{ SWAP_REQUEST : "offered_in_exchange"
  PHONE ||--o{ AVAIL_PHONE : "requested_phone"

errors: Content is too short or empty

attempts.content:
5. Adhere to formatting and style requirements
6. Refer to provided context for any additional instructions

Here is a Mermaid Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD) based on the given requirements and project context:
```mermaid
erDiagram
    USERS {
        id int PK
        name string
        email string
    }
    POSTS {
        id int PK
        title string
        content string
        user_id int FK
    }
    USERS ||--o{ POSTS : places
```
In this ERD, we have two entities: `USERS` and `POSTS`. The `USERS` entity has three fields: `id`, `name`, and `email`, which are the primary key (`PK`), a string field for the user's name, and an email address. The `POSTS` entity has four fields: `id`, `title`, `content`, and `user_id`, which are the primary key (`PK`), a string field for the post title, a text field for the post content, and a foreign key (`FK`) to reference the user who created the post. The relationship between the two entities is a one-to-many relationship, represented by the `||--o{ : places` symbol.

This ERD accurately represents the given requirements and project context, with all necessary fields and relationships included.

erDiagram
    USERS {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    POSTS {
        int id PK
        string title
        string content
        int user_id FK
    }
    USERS ||--o{ POSTS : places

The above ERD is based on the requirements provided, which include a Users table with id, name, and email fields, and a Posts table with id, title, content, and user_id field. The cardinality of the relationship between Users and Posts is one-to-many, as each user can have multiple posts but each post belongs to only one user.

The ERD includes the necessary entities and relationships, and the syntax is valid Mermaid code.

Here is the Mermaid ERD based on the provided requirements and project context:
```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    POST {
        int id PK
        string title
        string content
        int user_id FK
    }
    USER ||--o{ POST : places
```
Note that the ERD includes the `USER` and `POST` entities, with a one-to-many relationship between them based on the `user_id` field in the `POST` table. The cardinality is represented by the `||--o{` syntax, which indicates a one-to-many relationship from the `USER` entity to the `POST` entity.

Here is the generated Mermaid ERD diagram based on the provided requirements and project context:

```
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    POSTS {
        int id PK
        string title
        string content
        int user_id FK
    }
    USER ||--o{ POSTS : has many posts
```

Here is a Mermaid ERD diagram based on the provided requirements, project context, and snippets:

```
erDiagram
    USER {
        string id PK
        string email
        string name
    }
    POST {
        int id PK
        string title
        text content
        USER ||--o{ POST : user
    }
    USER ||--* POST : has many posts

```

The diagram includes the `USER` and `POST` entities, with their respective attributes. The relationship between `USER` and `POST` is one-to-many (one user can have multiple posts), represented by the `||--o{` notation.

Please note that this ERD diagram only captures the essence of the provided snippets and may not be a comprehensive representation of the entire project context.

Here is the Mermaid ERD based on the provided requirements and project context:

```
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    POST {
        int id PK
        string title
        text content
        int user_id FK references User(id)
    }
```

Here is the Mermaid ERD based on the provided requirements and project context:
```
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    POST {
        int id PK
        string title

```

metadata.html_content:
🎨 Mermaid Diagram Visualization

attempts.content:
5. Maintain a cohesive structure and readability
6. Use your intelligence to fill in any missing gaps
7. Evaluate the relevance of each snippet
8. Provide the most accurate descriptions

5. Check for plagiarism and originality
6. Convert to new formats if required
7. Provide any additional context or requirements
8. Adhere to privacy policies and agreements
9. Exclude any inappropriate content
10. Respect authorship and licenses

5. Adhere to formatting requirements
6. Provide clear, concise, and accurate instructions
7. Exclude irrelevant information

5. Adhere to required format and style
6. Maintain consistency and coherence throughout
7. Provide clear and unambiguous instructions

Here is a Mermaid ERD based on the given requirements and project context:
```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER {
        id int PK
        name string
        email string
    }
    ORDER {
        id int PK
        user_id int FK
        amount decimal
        status string
    }
    USER ||--o{ ORDER : places
```
The ERD includes the following entities:

* `USER`: has an integer primary key, name, and email.
* `ORDER`: has an integer primary key, a foreign key to the user who placed the order, amount, and status.

There is a one-to-many relationship between `USER` and `ORDER`, with each user having multiple orders. The cardinality of this relationship is indicated by the "o" symbol in the ERD.

erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    ORDER {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        datetime created_at
    }
    USER ||--o{ ORDER : places
```
This ERD shows a one-to-many relationship between the `USER` and `ORDER` entities. The `ORDER` entity has a foreign key (`user_id`) that references the primary key (`id`) of the `USER` entity. This indicates that an order can be placed by only one user, and each user can have multiple orders.

The ERD also includes a cardinality notation in the form of `X o Y : relationship_label`, where `X` and `Y` are entities and `:relationship_label` is a label for the relationship between them. In this case, the cardinality notation is `USER ||--o{ ORDER : places`. The arrowheads indicate the direction of the relationship (from `USER` to `ORDER`), and the `places` label gives a brief description of the relationship.

erDiagram
    USERS {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    ORDERS {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        decimal amount
        varchar status
    }
    USERS ||--o{ ORDERS : places
```

Here is the Mermaid ERD diagram code based on the provided requirements and project context:
```
erDiagram
    USER {
        Guid id PK
        string email
        string name
    }
    ORDER {
        int id PK
        Guid user_id FK
        decimal amount
        string status
    }

    USER ||--o{ ORDER : places
```

Here is the generated Mermaid ERD:
```
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    ORDER {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK references USER(id)
        datetime created_at
        decimal amount
        string status
    }
```

Here is the ERD diagram in Mermaid syntax based on the provided requirements and project context:

```
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    ORDER {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK references USER(id)
        datetime created_at
        float amount
        string status
    }

    USER ||--o{ ORDER : places
```

Note: The provided code snippets do not contain any information about the entities and relationships between them. Therefore, I've used general terms like `USER` and `ORDER` to create a basic ERD diagram. If more specific details are available, please provide them, and I'll be happy to help you create a more accurate diagram.

Here is the generated Mermaid ERD based on the provided requirements and project context:

```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    ORDER {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        datetime created_at
        int amount
        string status
    }
    USER ||--o{ ORDER : places
```

Please note that this ERD is generated based on the provided requirements and project context, but it might not be a complete representation of your actual database schema. It's always recommended to double-check the accuracy and completeness of your ERDs before using them in production.

metadata.meeting_notes:
Phone Swap Request Feature
Date: October 14, 2025
Attendees: Product Manager, UX Designer, Lead Frontend Developer, Lead Backend Developer
Objective: Define the requirements and implementation plan fo
metadata.html_content:
🎨 Mermaid Diagram Visualization

📊 Interactive Diagram

Diagram ID: erd_diagram

attempts.content:
Here's a clean, correct Entity-Relationship Diagram (ERD) in Mermaid syntax for the given project context:
```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER ||--o{ ORDER : places
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    ORDER {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        datetime created_at
    }
```
This ERD includes all the necessary entities and relationships between them, including the cardinalities for each relationship. It also adheres to the syntax requirements mentioned in the prompt, including using the `erDiagram` keyword and not using class or ->.

Please note that this is a simplified diagram and may not capture all the details of the actual project context.

erDiagram
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    ORDER {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        datetime created_at
    }
    PHONE {
        int id PK
        string brand
        string model
        int storage
        float price
    }
    USER ||--o{ ORDER : places
    ORDER }o--|{ PHONE : contains
```

This diagram represents the entities, relationships, and cardinalities between them. The `USER` entity has three attributes: `id`, `name`, and `email`. The `ORDER` entity has three attributes: `id`, `user_id`, and `created_at`. The `PHONE` entity has four attributes: `id`, `brand`, `model`, `storage`, and `price`.

The relationships between the entities are represented by the lines. The `USER ||--o{ ORDER : places` line indicates that a user can have many orders, and each order is associated with a specific user. The `ORDER }o--|{ PHONE : contains` line indicates that an order can contain many phones, and each phone belongs to one order.

The cardinalities of the relationships are also included in the diagram. For example, the `USER ||--o{ ORDER : places` line shows that a user has a one-to-many relationship with orders, meaning that a user can have multiple orders but an order can only belong to one user. Similarly, the `ORDER }o--|{ PHONE : contains` line shows that an order has a one-to-many relationship with phones, meaning that an order can contain many phones but each phone can only belong to one order.

Overall, this ERD provides a clear and concise representation of the entities, relationships, and cardinalities between them, which is essential for understanding the structure and behavior of the system being modeled.

Here's a Mermaid Entity-Relationship Diagram for the given requirements:
```mermaid
erDiagram
    User {
        id int PK
        name string
        email string
    }
    Phone {
        id int PK
        user_id int FK
        brand string
        model string
        storage int
        price float
    }
    SwapRequest {
        id int PK
        phone_to_request_id int FK
        phone_to_exchange_id int FK
        reason text
    }
    User ||--o{ Phone : places
    Phone ||--o{ SwapRequest : requests
```
This ERD includes the following entities and relationships:

* `User` entity with attributes `id`, `name`, and `email`.
* `Phone` entity with attributes `id`, `user_id`, `brand`, `model`, `storage`, and `price`. The `user_id` attribute is a foreign key that references the `id` attribute of the `User` entity.
* `SwapRequest` entity with attributes `id`, `phone_to_request_id`, `phone_to_exchange_id`, and `reason`. The `phone_to_request_id` and `phone_to_exchange_id` attributes are foreign keys that reference the `id` attribute of the `Phone` entity.
* A one-to-many relationship between `User` and `Phone` entities, where a user can have multiple phones but a phone can only belong to one user.
* A many-to-many relationship between `Phone` and `SwapRequest` entities, where a phone can be requested for swap multiple times and a swap request can involve multiple phones.

Here is the Mermaid ERD code based on the provided requirements and project context:

```
erDiagram
    PHONE {
        int id PK
        string brand
        string model
        int storage
        int price
    }
    USER {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    SWAP_REQUEST {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK references USER
        int requested_phone_id FK references PHONE
        int offered_phone_id FK references PHONE
        string reason_for_request (optional)
        enum status (Pending, Approved, Rejected)
    }
    PHONES_OWNED_BY_USER {
        int user_id FK references USER
        int phone_id FK references PHONE
    }
    PHONE_SERVICE {
        list<Phone> phones
    }
```

Note: The ERD diagram includes the following entities and relationships:

* `PHONE`: represents a phone with its attributes (brand, model, storage, price).
* `USER`: represents a user with its attributes (id, name, email).
* `SWAP_REQUEST`: represents a swap request between two phones with additional information about the reason for the request and its status.
* `PHONES_OWNED_BY_USER`: represents a many-to-many relationship between a user and their owned phones.
* `PHONE_SERVICE`: represents a service that manages a list of phones.

Please review the ERD diagram to ensure it meets your requirements.

Here is the Mermaid ERD based on the provided requirements and project context:

```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER {
        string id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    PHONE {
        int id PK
        string brand
        string model
        int storage
        double price
    }
    SWAP_REQUEST {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK references USER(id)
        int phone_id_fk references PHONE(id)
        string comment
        bool status default "Pending"
    }
    PHONE_SERVICE {
        +getPhones(): Observable<PHONE[]>
        +addPhone(phone: PHONE): void
        +updatePhone(phone: PHONE): void
        +deletePhone(phoneId: number): void
    }

    USER ||--o{ SWAP_REQUEST : makes
    PHONE ||--o{ SWAP_REQUEST : requested
    PHONE_SERVICE }o--o{ PHONE : manages
```

Note that this ERD represents the entities and relationships described in the provided requirements and project context, including the `PHONE` entity with its attributes, the `SWAP_REQUEST` entity representing the phone swap requests, and the `PHONE_SERVICE` entity representing the phone service API. The relationships between these entities are also represented, including the one-to-one relationship between a user and their swap requests, the one-to-many relationship between a phone and its swap requests, and the many-to-one relationship between a phone service and the phones it manages.

Here is the Mermaid ERD diagram based on the provided requirements and project context:

```
erDiagram
    User {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    Phone {
        int id PK
        string brand
        string model
        int storage
        float price
    }
    SwapRequest {
        int id PK
        int requester_id FK references User(id)
        int requested_phone_id FK references Phone(id)
        int offered_phone_id FK references Phone(id)
        string comment
        status: enum('Pending', 'Approved', 'Rejected')
    }
    PhoneService {
        getPhones(): Observable<Phone[]>
        addPhone(Phone phone): void
        updatePhone(Phone phone): void
        deletePhone(int phoneId): void
    }

    User ||--o{ SwapRequest : makes_request
    Phone ||--o{ SwapRequest : is_requested
    Phone ||--o{ SwapRequest : is_offered

    SwapRequest }o--o{ Phone : requested_phone
    SwapRequest }o--o{ Phone : offered_phone
```

This ERD diagram represents the entities and relationships required for the phone swap request feature. The `User` entity has a one-to-many relationship with the `SwapRequest` entity, as a user can make multiple swap requests. The `Phone` entity is related to the `SwapRequest` entity through two many-to-one relationships, representing the requested and offered phones in each swap request.

Here is the Mermaid ERD diagram based on the provided requirements and project context:
```
erDiagram
    User {
        int id PK
        string name
        string email
    }
    Phone {
        int id PK
        string brand
        string model
        int storage
        decimal price
    }
    SwapRequest {
        int id PK
        int userId FK references User(id)
        int phoneIdToRequest FK references Phone(id)
        int phoneIdToExchange FK references Phone(id)
        string reasonForRequest
        bool status default 'Pending'
    }
    APIEndpoint {
        string endpoint
        method POST
        response SwapRequest
    }
```
Note that this ERD diagram includes the entities `User`, `Phone`, and `SwapRequest`, as well as the relationships between them. The `APIEndpoint` entity represents the new API endpoint created to handle swap requests.

I hope this meets your requirements! Let me know if you have any further questions or need any additional assistance.

content:
erDiagram
    User {
        int id PK
        string username
        string email
        string password_hash
        string first_name
        string last_name
        datetime date_registered
        datetime last_login
        boolean is_active
        boolean email_verified
    }
    Role {
        int id PK
        string name
        string description
    }
    UserRole {
        int user_id PK,FK
        int role_id PK,FK
        datetime assigned_at
    }
    UserProfile {
        int user_id PK,FK
        date date_of_birth
        string gender
        text bio
        string profile_picture_url
        string phone_number
    }
    Address {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        string address_line1
        string address_line2
        string city
        string state_province
        string postal_code
        string country
        string address_type
        boolean is_default
    }
    ContactMethod {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK

content:
erDiagram
    User {
        int id PK
        string username UNIQUE
        string email UNIQUE
        string password_hash
        datetime created_at
        datetime updated_at
        datetime last_login_at
        boolean is_active
        boolean is_verified
    }

    UserProfile {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK UNIQUE
        string first_name
        string last_name
        text bio
        string avatar_url
        string location
        date birth_date
        string phone_number
    }

    Role {
        int id PK
        string name UNIQUE
        text description
    }

    Permission {
        int id PK
        string name UNIQUE
        text description
    }

    UserRole {
        int user_id FK
        int role_id FK
        datetime assigned_at
    }

    RolePermission {
        int role_id FK
        int permission_id FK
        datetime granted_at
    }

    Session {
        string id PK
        int user_id FK
        string token UNIQUE
        datetime expires_at
        datetime created_at
        string ip_address
        string user_agent
    }

    PasswordResetToken {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        string token UNIQUE
        datetime expires_at
        datetime created_at
        boolean is_used
    }

    EmailVerificationToken {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        string token UNIQUE
        datetime expires_at
        datetime created_at
        boolean is_used
    }

    UserSetting {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        string setting_key
        string setting_value
        datetime updated_at
    }

    AuditLog {
        int id PK
        int user_id FK
        string action
        string entity_type
        int entity_id
        text details
        string ip_address
        datetime timestamp
    }

    User ||--o| UserProfile : has
    User ||--o{ UserRole : has
    Role ||--o{ UserRole : assigned_to
    Role ||--o{ RolePermission : grants
    Permission ||--o{ RolePermission : granted_to
    User ||--o{ Session : creates
    User ||--o{ PasswordResetToken : generates
    User ||--o{ EmailVerificationToken : requests
    User ||--o{ UserSetting : configures
    User ||--o{ AuditLog : performs

erDiagram User { int id PK string username UNIQUE string email UNIQUE string password_hash datetime created_at datetime updated_at datetime last_login_at boolean is_active boolean is_verified } UserProfile { int id PK int user_id FK UNIQUE string first_name string last_name text bio string avatar_url string location date birth_date string phone_number } Role { int id PK string name UNIQUE text description } Permission { int id PK string name UNIQUE text description } UserRole { int user_id FK int role_id FK datetime assigned_at } RolePermission { int role_id FK int permission_id FK datetime granted_at } Session { string id PK int user_id FK string token UNIQUE datetime expires_at datetime created_at string ip_address string user_agent } PasswordResetToken { int id PK int user_id FK string token UNIQUE datetime expires_at datetime created_at boolean is_used } EmailVerificationToken { int id PK int user_id FK string token UNIQUE datetime expires_at datetime created_at boolean is_used } UserSetting { int id PK int user_id FK string setting_key string setting_value datetime updated_at } AuditLog { int id PK int user_id FK string action string entity_type int entity_id text details string ip_address datetime timestamp } User ||--o| UserProfile : has User ||--o{ UserRole : has Role ||--o{ UserRole : assigned_to Role ||--o{ RolePermission : grants Permission ||--o{ RolePermission : granted_to User ||--o{ Session : creates User ||--o{ PasswordResetToken : generates User ||--o{ EmailVerificationToken : requests User ||--o{ UserSetting : configures User ||--o{ AuditLog : performs
